docs.lead_paragraph: Members of the House and the Senate are steeped these days in the nitty-gritty of the health care debate. But for all the haggling, any bill's language is likely to be only one factor in how they vote on overhauling the nation's health care system. That is because all members of the House and one-third of the Senate are up for re-election next year. Many will consider various political and demographic realities in their home districts and states before they cast a vote, yea or nay.
docs.abstract: Many Senate and House members, facing re-election in 2010, are likely to consider various political and demographic realities in casting their votes on health care legislation; may consider factors such as whether district or state voted for Pres Obama in 2008 election, proportion of older people in district, whether lawmakers have already voted against prevailing views of their districts on other issues and pressure from special interests; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Members of the House and the Senate are steeped these days in the nitty-gritty of the health care debate. But for all the haggling, any bill's language is likely to be only one factor in how they vote on overhauling the nation's health care system.  ...

docs.lead_paragraph: My Sunday column returns to the health care debate. I look at some of the perverse consequences of having insurance companies able to reject people whom they think may get sick, and in particularly at the tribulations of David Waddington and his family. He needed a kidney transplant, and his sons wanted to donate -- but the testing to see if they could do so might have cost them the ability ever to get insurance. It was a nightmare scenario, and to me at least it's one more reminder of the utter moral bankruptcy of our existing system.

headline.main: Your Comments on My Sunday Health Column

docs.abstract: One more reason for universal health coverage: even trying to help out and donate an organ can cost somebody access to health insurance.
docs.snippet: One more reason for universal health coverage: even trying to help out and donate an organ can cost somebody access to health insurance.

docs.lead_paragraph: News Friday that unemployment has reached the highest level since the start of the recession - 9.8 percent - brought President Obama's stimulus package under renewed scrutiny as he returned from his visit with the International Olympic Committee in Copenhagen empty-handed. In weekly addresses this morning, Republicans continued to criticize the administration for "reckless spending" while Democrats rushed to highlight the silver lining.
